values:
A short assessment of various anime of which I have watched one or more episodes on Crunchyroll.

Blue Exorcist - Son of Satan decides to become an exorcist. Wacky hijinks ensue. My favorite so far.

Gosick - He's a Japanese exchange student. She's a Goth Loli. They solve mysteries in post-Great War Europe. Recommended.

Gintama - Instead of the Meiji restoration, aliens invaded. Hilarity ensues. Opening sequence definitely recommended.

Space Pirate Captain Harlock - Title says it all really. A classic.

Galaxy Express 999 - No one in this world ever gets what they want, and that is beautiful. Everybody dies frustrated and sad, and that is beautiful. But watch some Harlock first.

Sengoku Otome (a.k.a. Battle Girls) - Perfectly ordinary Japanese school girl is transported back into time to warring states era Japan. Where, for some reason, everybody is female (except the talking dog). Total guilty pleasure.

11 Eyes - Interesting premise that doesn't quite pan out. Bonus points for the Hungarian.

Tono to Issho - Japanese history as it didn't actually happen.

Panty and Stocking (with Garterbelt) - Gainax.

Astarotte's Toy - Ten year old succubus needs a harem.

Hanasaku Iroha - Girls at an inn. Maybe something happened? I don't remember.

Bridge to the Starry Skies - I got bored half way through and stopped watching.

We Without Wings - Did you know black people always speak in rap? Also, rape, ha ha ha!

SKET Dance - The one episode I watched was the sort of farce I hate, but it seemed like the series might have potential.

My Everyday Life - Fake Azumanga.

Let's Play! - Alien cat girls invade Earth for Korean BBQ. Why can't I stop watching?!

It's a testament to how neglected my LJ has been that I let the 29th slip by without fulfilling certain obligations. Also, I was able to find the text by Googling "mokushirokuology".

Gloria in excelsis Utenae
Et in mundo revolutio consilio discipulorum.
Laudamus te.
Pugnamus te.
Adoramus te.
Spondemus te.
Gratias agimus tibi propter Apocalyptem Sortis Absolutae tuam,
Domina Utena, Princeps Ohtori, Utena Pugnatrix omnivicens.
Domina Puella Revolutionaria, Tenjou Utena.
Domina Utena, Sponsa Anthiae Nuptae Roseae.
Quae efficis revolutionem mundi, supera nobis.
Quae efficis revolutionem mundi, errumpe putamen nobis.
Quae pugnas sub castello inverto, supera nobis.
Quoniam tu sola Victrix.
Tu sola Revolutionaria.
Tu sola Pugnatrix, Tenjou Utena
Cum absoluta sorte sub castello inverto.
Et dicamus: AM-MON-ITGlory in the highest to Utena
And revolution in the world for the student counsel.
We praise you.
We duel you.
We adore you.
We engage you.
We give thanks to you for your Absolute Destiny Apocalypse.
O Utena-sama, Prince of Ohtori, Utena the ever-victorious Deulist.
O Miss Revolutionary Girl, Tenjou Utena.
O Utena-sama, the engaged of Anthy the Rose Bride.
You who bring about the world revolution, win for us.
You who bring about the world revolution, cause our shell to be broken.
You who duel beneath the upside-down castle, win for us.
For you alone are Victorious.
You alone are Revolutionary.
You alone are the Duelist, Tenjou Utena
With an absolute destiny beneath the upside-down castle.
And let us say: AM-MON-ITE!

At some point during college, I wound up on the email list of the Israeli consulate in LA. I've been too lazy to take myself off of it, and my spam filter seems to catch most of it anyway, but I occasionally get notices about various events and movies being shown. 

Today I got an email about a showing of "Hazman Havarod", a documentary about the gay rights movement in Israel. Forty-five minutes later I got another email telling me to disregard the previous email as it had been sent due to a "technical error".

I will be around on Monday but will be unable to partake of anything made from wheat, barley, oats, rye, or spelt. Corn, rice, legumes, and other grainish substances are extremely iffy (it's complicated). What I will eat: Animal protein, dairy products, fruits, most green vegetables, anything with a "Kosher for Passover" label.
And as I much prefer Red Indians to Turks, not to mention Jews, I speak without prejudice - G. K. Chesterton, What I Saw in America

The Cat Piano from PRA on Vimeo.

I was negligent about blogging my PAX experience last year. This year, I would like to avoid that, so before going to bed, I give you the highlights of my Friday at PAX 2009:

  • Played the Batman: Arkham Asylum demo. I couldn't even hear the dialogue, and it still convinced me it's time to break down and get an Xbox 360.
  • Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle nostalgia tripping. The TMNT: Smash Up game was actually quite fun, to the extent I might even consider getting it, and I happily wore a TMNT: 25th anniversary pin around the rest of the day. Also, full size Turtle Bus!
  • I made an impulse buy of a sanely priced, used copy of Dragon Quest VIII, but I'm not sure I'll ever actually get around to playing it.
  • The following diaglouge during a discussion about cosplaying con-goers: Dave: And there was someone dressed as an Earthbound character. Me: Really? I don't remember seeing anything like that. Dave: Yeah. Some one was dressed as Paula. Me: Oh. Wow! That was Paula! She seems a lot less creepy now. I saw her again latter, and she actually still seemed pretty creepy.
  • Race for the Galaxy is a fun table-top game.
  • I participated in the attempt to set a world-record for most DSs played simultaneously in a single gathering. I made sure Suikoden got representation.
  • I was sad to discover that Toho Studio lawyers finally set their guns on Seattle gaming fixture Pink Godzilla Games.
  • Mario Kart 64 is still the best of the Mario Kart games.
  • Skipped the Anamanaguchi concert as I wasn't very impressed with them last year. I was drafted into a game of Settlers outside the concert hall, and from what I could hear, they sounded better from the outside then they did from the inside.
  • Metroid Metal rocked. I would have personally preferred something less metal, and more prog, but they gave a great high energy performance. I was actually disappointed in the crowd. If I hadn't been carrying a giant swag bag at the time, I would have probably moved forward where the crowd was getting more into the music. In any case, I couldn't stand still. I plan to pick up their album tomorrow if I can. The line tonight was too long, and it was already very late.

All ye would be engineers of language, ye fight not a losing battle but a battle that is already lost Language doesn't work that way. The name is not the cause of the contempt; rather, the name takes on the contempt toward the named.

Hearts cannot feel emotions England[AP]- You do not feel with your heart horrible cold-hearted scientests announced yesterday, saying this to make up for their own inability to love. The bad science men explained that the heart can only pump blood and if you feel sad or joyful that is your brain and not your heart. Whether tears come directly from the heart is still uncertain despite the meddling of these pathetic robot-like men who can feel nothing but jealously for normal people. I hate these scientest men, I hate them with my heart.

For a while now I've heard very good things about the feature-length, mythological, autobiographical, animated, musical, one-woman production Sita Sings the Blues. It hasn't seen release due to copy right restrictions on the songs, but it's now available online. I finally watched it and it deserves all the praise it's getting. If you have some free time to spare, you should definitely watch it.

Once again the secret to enjoying things turns out to be low expectations. I saw Watchmen expecting to be able to denounce it as an abomination legitimately. I wanted to hate it, but I couldn't. Yes, it was a shallow copy of a very deep book, but it was a highly entertaining shallow copy.

I was woken up last night by an extremely bright light shining directly in my face. When I went to the window to see what the hell was going on outside, I realized that it was the moon!

Via the application of cold logic and demonstrate that I am probably a horrible person. First a preamble: The following thoughts were occasioned by the recent Israeli incursion into Gaza. I think this action is plainly unjustified and immoral due to the fact that the Israelis are lashing out and endangering innocent lives without any clear goals. They have clearly fallen into the "We have to do something! This is something! We have to do this!" trap. That being said, the following occurs to me: Gaza is essentially an anarchic region without any rule of law, whatever nominal authority Hamas might posses. In such areas occupation is always futile since an effective occupation involves seizing the reigns of power, and in places like Gaza, no reigns of power exist to be seized. The only effective means to conduct relations with a lawless region are to ignore it, isolate yourself from it, or conquer it. Ignoring rockets being launched into your territory is an obvious non-starter. I'm not convinced Israel has adequately attempted to isolate itself from Gaza, but assuming for a moment that it had, this would leave systematic conquest (as opposed to taking pot shots at anyone who pisses you off) as the only option and effectively make it a form of self-defense. If the idea of conquest as self-defense does not seem bizarre enough, consider that anyone who resisted a conquest-in-self-defense would be resisting a legitimate authority and thus, ipso facto, not innocent. None of which is to say that any and all possible actions by the conquerors would be licit in such circumstances. Please keep in mind that I'm more interested in arguing about the merits of the abstract conclusion than whether the specific situation actually fits it.

One of the dangers of reading the bible in the original is the puns of incredibly high magnitude. 

Take for example Genesis 37:5, 

vay-yachalom yoseif chalom vay-yaggeid l'echayv vay-yosifu 'od s'no otho.

A literal translation of which is "And dreamed Joseph a dream and he told to his brothers and they josephed more hatred of him". 

It's not like I shouldn't have seen this coming, however. Joseph was in introduced in Genesis 30:24 with the line 

vat-tiqrah eth-sh'mo yoseif leimor yoseif HASHEM li bein acheir. 

And she called his name Joseph, to say "Joseph the Lord for me another son".

Amid all the ephemeral thoughts I've been meaning to post on LJ but I haven't written, I think maybe I should just get a Twitter account and post one-liners as they occur to me. Instead of a post about how nouning isn't licensed at all in my idiolect I could just state it out right without any analysis when I notice it. Also I would have an excuse to post bizarre, non-sensical sentences that would make Sam & Max proud.

Found in the Wikipedia entry for Delicatessen: The use of the word 'deli' in ancient Australian dialect also refers to the infamous greek bushranger, Daniel Dan Deli. His most famous catch phrase is still used today, "on a stick."

I hate smokers even more now. I was walking home today and one decided to use the side walk for an ash try as I was walking under his balcony. And this is the sort of nonsense that makes Descriptivists hate Prescriptivists. Yes, let's all avoid using words that look or sound like other words. That's a grate wonderful idea!

I just went to get some water at work. There were two people talking about "orginal vowels". One of them is Israeli, and I think they were talking about the historical pronounciation and pointing of the Masoretic text of the Hebrew Bible. I had to force myself not to join in the conversation. I still kind of want to drop what I'm doing and just go back there.

Man, but that's my kind of water cooler conversation.

I saw tomorrow's xkcd and did not understand it . If you are still fortunate enough to not understand it yourself, do not attempt to do so. I repeat: DO NOT attempt to understand the xkcd for August 25, 2008. You will be sorry if you do, and I say this as someone who merely read the relevant wikipedia page.

Yesterday I came across this interesting online Survey of American Jewish Language. They're specifically looking for non-Jews to take the survey, so all you goyim should head on over. It only took me about ten minutes, and they promised the version for non-Jews was much shorter.

I generally consider cosplaying a line which shouldnot be crossed, but upon seeing a not-yet-updated Penny Arcade for a second time this morning, I had an epiphany. Much pleasure could no doubt be had by cosplaying as Ilpalazzo and denouncing the moral degeneracy of the other con goers. Why the rants about the tentacle-monster agenda in our schools alone...
